newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crudes steady, two-tier market for Minas.
newsitem.headline: Asian crudes steady, two-tier market for Minas.

text.p: The heavy sweet Asian crude market saw little change, but a two tier market developed amid thin demand as June sellers continued to outnumber buyers.
Shosha with June barrels were aggressive, selling at lower premiums to Japanese refiners to dispose of barrels. But western traders were holding out for stronger prices.
A trader sold June Minas to China this week at ICP +25 cents.
This compared with ICP +15 cents that a Japanese refiner paid for its barrels on Wednesday and the ICP +17 cts that an Indonesian affiliate achieved for its Minas trade to a shosha.
Offers of Thevenard Island and North West Shelf condensate by Australian refiners for June were keeping the light Asian grades under pressure.
But North West Shelf demand in July could increase, due to a shortage of Indonesia's Arun condensate, traders said.
Indonesia did not allocate any Arun condensate to its affiliates for June exports. Traders attributed this to the start-up of a new condensate splitter in Indonesia.

The tighter outlook for condensate spot supplies has supported North West Shelf condensate levels, with July cargoes expected to trade around Arun APPI +50 cts for July cargoes. In Middle East trade, A July Oman was rumoured sold by a South Korean refiner to China at MPM -10 cts. The trade could not be confirmed, but traders thought the level was a fair reflection of the July Oman market.
Lighter crudes from Abu Dhabi and Qatar are expected to start trading at wider discounts, as Japanese refiners have high inventory stocks of middle distillates.
